title: ICE "no entry for node id" (new_named_lifetime_with_res in rustc_ast_lowering)

labels.name: I-ICE
labels.description: Issue: The compiler panicked, giving an Internal Compilation Error (ICE) ❄️

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Found by fuzzing with a [modified fuzz-rustc](https://github.com/jruderman/fuzz-rustc) ### Code The compiler panics while compiling this code ([playground](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=a3cfcf51d981b2a50c9e43377beddfe5)). It then panics a second time while trying to explain why it panicked. ```Rust struct S { _t: T } fn f(S::<&i8> { .. }: S<&i8>) { } fn main() { f(S { _t: &42_i8 }); } ``` I believe this is a valid Rust program, based on the variants below that compile successfully. ### Meta `rustc --version --verbose`: ``` rustc 1.66.0-nightly (b8b5caee0 2022-10-16) binary: rustc commit-hash: b8b5caee04116c7383eb1c6470fcf15c437a60d4 commit-date: 2022-10-16 host: x86_64-apple-darwin release: 1.66.0-nightly LLVM version: 15.0.2 ``` ### Error output ``` thread 'rustc' panicked at 'no entry for node id: `NodeId(39)`', compiler/rustc_ast_lowering/src/lib.rs:530:55 query stack during panic: thread 'rustc' panicked at 'already borrowed: BorrowMutError', /rustc/b8b5caee04116c7383eb1c6470fcf15c437a60d4/compiler/rustc_query_system/src/query/plumbing.rs:372:11 ```
Full output with both backtraces

std::sys::unix::thread::Thread::new::thread_start::h8c17323206c3f1d4 87: 0x7ff813a244e1 - __pthread_start error: internal compiler error: unexpected panic note: the compiler unexpectedly panicked. this is a bug. note: we would appreciate a bug report: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/new?labels=C-bug%2C+I-ICE%2C+T-compiler&template=ice.md note: rustc 1.66.0-nightly (b8b5caee0 2022-10-16) running on x86_64-apple-darwin query stack during panic: thread panicked while processing panic. aborting. Abort trap: 6 ```

### Variants that do not crash It compiles successfully if I change `&i8` to `_` in the paramter's pattern: ``` struct S { _t: T } fn f(S::<_> { .. }: S<&i8>) { } fn main() { f(S { _t: &42_i8 }); } ``` It also compiles successfully if I change the reference to specify the `'static` lifetime throughout: ``` struct S { _t: T } fn f(S::<&'static i8> { .. }: S<&'static i8>) { } fn main() { f(S { _t: &42_i8 }); } ```
